author: By J. David Goodman
title: Man Gets 100 Years in Prison for His Role in 2020 Shooting Spree
description: The rampage on Thanksgiving Day killed one person and injured several others in Nevada and Arizona.
content: A Texas man has been sentenced to at least 100 years in prison for his part in a two-state shooting spree on Thanksgiving Day in 2020 that killed one person and wounded several others across Nevada and Arizona.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Selig
title: Colonel Found Guilty of Sexual Harassment in Trial Seen as a Milestone
description: The conviction is considered one of the first of its kind since Congress required the military to change how its legal system addresses sexual assault and harassment.
content: A former Army battalion commander has been found guilty in a military court of sexually harassing a subordinate, one of the first cases of its kind brought after an overhaul of the military’s legal system that established sexual harassment as a criminal offense.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karoun Demirjian
title: Graham Says Hegseth Plans to Release Accuser From Confidential Agreement
description: Senator Lindsey Graham said that Pete Hegseth, President-elect Donald Trump’s defense secretary pick, promised to release his accuser from a settlement that his lawyer has said was already breached.
content: Pete Hegseth, President-elect Donald J. Trump’s pick to lead the Defense Department, told Senator Lindsey Graham of South Carolina that he planned to release the woman who accused him of sexual assault from a confidential settlement agreement, Mr. Graham said on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee
title: Israel Strikes Military Sites in Syria, Monitor Says
description: The Israeli military hit weapons depots and air defenses, according to the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights. Israel has said it aims to keep military equipment away from extremists.
content: Israel struck Syrian weapons depots and air defenses overnight, a group monitoring the conflict said Sunday, in what appeared to be part of an effort Israel says is aimed at depriving “extremists” of military assets after rebels seized power in Syria.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Otis
title: Walt Disney, Painted Out of the Photo
description: A photo found in The New York Times’s clippings library held a secret: One famous figure had been cropped out in order to spotlight another.
content: Jeff Roth, the caretaker of the morgue, The New York Times’s clippings and photo archive, was looking through the file of Igor Stravinsky, the Russian composer, this year when he discovered a curious black-and-white photo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Singer
title: An Epidemic of Vicious School Brawls, Fueled by Student Cellphones
description: Cafeteria melees. Students kicked in the head. Injured educators. Technology is stoking cycles of violence in schools across the United States.
content: Ricardo Martinez, an 11th grader, was in his high school lunchroom in April when a mass brawl erupted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Waterman
title: My 500-Mile Journey Across Alaska’s Thawing Arctic
description: I had read about how the rapid warming of the Arctic was upending the landscape and its people. Now I’ve seen it.
content: Flames were leaping out of the forest beneath the float plane taking us deep into the remote interior of northern Alaska. Our destination was the glacial Walker Lake, which stretches 14 miles through Gates of the Arctic National Park.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: Two Alvin Ailey Productions Head for the Light
description: Hope Boykin’s “Finding Free” and Lar Lubovitch’s “Many Angels” aspire to find higher ground at New York City Center.
content: Dancers moving from being scorned to rocking their souls in the bosom of Abraham — this is the narrative arc of Alvin Ailey’s masterpiece, “Revelations.” And that redemptive passage into the light is the template that many choreographers for Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater try to replicate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: Israel Shutters Its Embassy in Ireland, Citing ‘Anti-Israel Policies’
description: Amid mounting international criticism of its military conduct in Gaza, Israel says it will deepen ties with countries it considers friendly toward it.
content: Israel announced on Sunday that it was closing its embassy in Dublin in light of what it described as “the extreme anti-Israel policies of the Irish government.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi, busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. Enter the comments section to see hints, conversation, helpful tips and creative content from other solvers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 554
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Monday, Dec. 16, 2024.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Goodridge
title: A Trip to New York
description: Expert advice to make the most of a New York City vacation.
content: It’s prime Yuletide in New York City.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Devin Gordon, Eric Jason Martin, Jack D'Isidoro, Krish Seenivasan, Emma Kehlbeck, John Woo, Aaron Esposito, Catherine Anderson and Brian St Pierre
title: The Sunday Read: ‘What if A.I. Is Actually Good for Hollywood?’
description: It’s already powering remarkable visual innovations, like in the new movie “Here.” But boosters think that’s just the beginning.
content: “You couldn’t have made this movie three years ago,” said Robert Zemeckis, the director of “Here.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Don’t Cut an Agency So Vital to Our Health
description: Readers worry about cuts to the National Institutes of Health. Also: Maternity wards; overdose deaths; vetting presidential candidates; tech tycoons in charge.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: ​After Impeachment, South Korea Is Left With No Elected Leader
description: The suspension of President Yoon Suk Yeol’s powers left a seasoned but unelected prime minister in charge of a country facing daunting challenges at home and abroad.
content: President Yoon Suk Yeol’s impeachment and suspension from office has left South Korea, one of the United States’ most important allies, without a strong​ elected leader to tackle challenges like a belligerent North Korea and a deepening political polarization at home.​
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacob Gallagher
title: The Rise of the Noodle Boys
description: As an era of macho politics sets in, sinewy stars like Timothée Chalamet, Dominic Sessa and Mark Eydelshteyn embody a slinky alternative image of white masculinity in American pop culture.
content: He’s reedy like a long-distance runner; his flopsy curls tumble like overcooked fusilli. He’s attractive but in a way you can’t always put your finger on. He’s Hollywood’s white boy of the moment, and he has ambled into the movie industry to counter the broad and built look that the Marvel cinematic onslaught helped usher in during the 2000s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Esther Zuckerman
title: When ‘The Lord of the Rings’ Gets the Anime Treatment
description: “The War of the Rohirrim” is the latest and most high-profile anime adaptation of a Western franchise to hit screens big and small.
content: When Warner Bros. approached the filmmaker Peter Jackson and his longtime screenwriting partner Philippa Boyens about making a new animated “Lord of the Rings,” Boyens at first had a hard time wrapping her head around the notion. But when studio executives suggested that the film could be told via Japanese anime — suddenly it clicked.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Enrich
title: Trump and His Picks Threaten More Lawsuits Over Critical Coverage
description: The small flurry of threatened defamation suits is the latest sign that the incoming Trump administration appears poised to do what it can to crack down on unfavorable media coverage.
content: The legal threats have arrived in various forms. One aired on CNN. Another came over the phone. More arrived in letters or emails.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Holland Cotter
title: Lorraine O’Grady, Artist Who Defied Category, Is Dead at 90
description: She worked in collage, photography, performance, video and installation, and she dealt forthrightly with the complexities of race and gender.
content: Lorraine O’Grady, a conceptual artist who had careers as a research economist, literary translator and rock critic before producing her first art in her 40s, and who went on to influence a generation of younger Black artists, died on Friday at her home in Manhattan. She was 90.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: On ‘S.N.L.,’ Luigi Mangione Is Busting Out All Over
description: As Chris Rock hosts, the man charged in the UnitedHealthcare shooting dominates this week’s riffs on the news.
content: The 50th season of “Saturday Night Live” continues to provide the show with opportunities to revive many of its long-running characters. Last week, it was the Church Lady; this week, it was Nancy Grace, the TV personality and frequently outraged true-crime commentator, who has been frequently impersonated on “S.N.L.” over the years by cast members including Ana Gasteyer and Amy Poehler.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Dec. 14, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Dec. 14, 2024.
content: An article on Friday about an agreement reached by the city of Louisville, Ky., and the Justice Department to address misconduct by Louisville police misstated the circumstances by which the police in Louisville searched the home of Breonna Taylor, who was fatally shot by officers. The police department had approval for a no-knock warrant to enter Ms. Taylor’s apartment, but officers were later instructed to knock and identify themselves. It is not the case that they used no warrant at all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffery C. Mays
title: Hochul May Face a Challenger She Knows Well: Her Lieutenant Governor
description: Lt. Gov. Antonio Delgado has begun to carve out his own political path, potentially putting him on a collision course with his boss, Gov. Kathy Hochul.
content: In the two months leading up to Election Day, Lt. Gov. Antonio Delgado’s schedule was booked solid, but not with the typical ribbon cuttings associated with the somewhat anonymous job of being New York’s No. 2.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Solomon
title: A Christmas Gnome Tradition, More than 1,000-Strong
description: The writer Andrew Solomon recounts his enduring love for the cheerful little heroes of Swedish folklore, handed down from his late mother.
content: First, advent calendars; then gnomes; then the tree; and then Christmas itself. Only as an adult did I discover that one element in this sequence separated us from other New York families. In my early childhood, my mother, awakened to a novel festive touch by a Swiss friend with Swedish tastes, had collected more than a hundred little hand-carved wooden figures — Scandinavian gnomes, dressed in red, mostly with cotton-wool hair.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How Biden Should Spend His Final Weeks in Office
description: The president can still do a lot before he leaves the White House.
content: The days are dwindling to a precious few before President Biden relinquishes his tenancy at the White House to Donald Trump. Four years ago, in his inaugural address, Mr. Biden promised to “press forward with speed and urgency, for we have much to do in this winter of peril and possibility.” The peril remains, but so do the possibilities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laurie Zoloth
title: For the Sake of 600,000 Children, Science Must Be Bold
description: Gene drives offer hope in our battle against malaria.
content: Bold ideas in science research used to thrill us; now they seem pretty threatening. When I have written about the ethics of genetically engineered mosquitoes to combat malaria, many of my friends have expressed alarm. “What if it goes badly wrong?” they ask. What if there are unintended consequences that ripple across ecosystems? What if this is one of those technologies that cross the line from innovative to utterly world-destroying?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Garnaut and Sam Chetwin George
title: This Unreadable Russian Novel Is Xi Jinping’s Spiritual Guide
description: The Chinese leader is digging into the language of revolution, and a radical Russian novel, as he prepares for battle with Donald Trump.
content: In late October, while much of the world was focused on the buildup to the U.S. elections, President Xi Jinping of China was issuing a call for global resistance to the American-led world order.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Josh Stephens
title: One Ski Resort’s Long-Shot Bet to Survive Low Snowfall and Devastating Wildfires
description: The closest ski hill to Los Angeles recently sold to an investment group with big plans. But can those ideas work amid catastrophic climate threats that continue to plague the mountain?
content: For much of its 85-year existence, the Mount Waterman resort has drawn skiers and outdoor enthusiasts from around Los Angeles for its no-fuss, no-frills experience.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hank Sanders
title: Trump Says He Supports an End to Daylight Saving Time
description: President-elect Donald J. Trump said on social media that the time change is “inconvenient” and that the Republican Party would try to put an end to it.
content: President-elect Donald J. Trump called daylight saving time “inconvenient, and very costly to our Nation” in a social media post on Friday and said the Republican Party would try to “eliminate” it, in the latest effort to end the twice-yearly time change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Polly Mellen, Fashion’s Storied Cheerleader, Dies at 100
description: With photographers like Richard Avedon, Irving Penn, Bert Stern and others, the veteran editor created some of the most indelible images of modern fashion.
content: Polly Mellen, the irrepressible and indomitable fashion editor who was the last link to a long golden age when fashion editors were fearsome creatures who ruled by fiat, and a photograph in Vogue magazine, where Ms. Mellen worked for more than a quarter century, moved not just markets but the culture, died on Wednesday in Salisbury, Conn. She was 100 — an attractive round number, which Ms. Mellen, ever the perfectionist, surely appreciated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David French
title: The Trouble Began When #MeToo Became #ChurchToo
description: Yes, people want justice — as long as justice costs them nothing or very little.
content: When did we know that the #MeToo moment was truly over?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William K. Rashbaum, Dana Rubinstein, Emma G. Fitzsimmons and Chelsia Rose Marcius
title: Grand Jury Said to Hear Evidence Against Chief Adviser to Mayor Adams
description: Prosecutors with the Manhattan district attorney’s office have presented evidence that is focused at least in part on Ingrid Lewis-Martin, who was the top aide to Eric Adams until her resignation.
content: Manhattan prosecutors investigating corruption allegations against Ingrid Lewis-Martin, the chief adviser to Mayor Eric Adams, have presented evidence to a grand jury and could seek an indictment as soon as this week, people with knowledge of the matter said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiba Yazbek
title: Israel’s Military Strikes Northern Gaza After Days of Deadly Bombardment
description: Israel’s military said it carried out strikes and raids against Hamas targets in northern Gaza on Sunday. The actions followed days of deadly attacks across the territory.
content: Israel’s military said it carried out strikes and raids in northern Gaza on Sunday after days of deadly bombardments across the territory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Wordle Review No. 1,276
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Monday, Dec. 16, 2024.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Faller in Fall
description: Ailee Yoshida crafts her origin story.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlotta Gall and David Guttenfelder
title: ‘They Had the Desire to Return’
description: Elated residents are trickling home to their shattered Syrian town, a rebel stronghold controlled until recently by the government.
content: The skies were quiet the other night in the northwestern town of Tel Rifaat, Syria, and relief was palpable among fighters and civilians who have lived for years under the constant threat of bombardment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing
title: Automakers Thrived in the Pandemic. Many Are Now Struggling.
description: Changing technology, political turmoil and competition from China are cutting into profits and forcing carmakers to cut jobs and close factories.
content: A few years ago, automakers were celebrating record profits as the pandemic created shortages of new cars, allowing them to raise prices. Now the hangover is setting in.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Jacobs
title: It’s Hard to Be the Brother of a Genius Who Died Young
description: In “Ira Gershwin: A Life in Words,” Michael Owen offers a sympathetic portrait of the lyricist, overshadowed in a life that had him tending the legacy of his younger sibling George.
content: The lyricist Ira Gershwin once suggested his epitaph should be “Words Failed Me”: a joke tinged with ineffable sadness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eli Saslow and Erin Schaff
title: The Alienation of Jaime Cachua
description: His friends and family members in Rome, Ga., voted to support mass deportation. Now he’s scrambling to stay in the country.
content: His wife was spiraling into insomnia, and his children were afraid to go to school, so Jaime Cachua sought out the person he trusted most in a crisis. He sat at his kitchen table in rural Georgia across from his father-in-law, Sky Atkins, the family patriarch. Jaime, 33, hadn’t seen his own father since he was 10 months old, when he left Mexico in a car seat bound for the United States. It was Sky, 45, who had stood by Jaime at his wedding, helped him move into his first house and stayed at the hospital overnight when one of Jaime’s children was sick with pneumonia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane and Mike Belleme
title: Saving Christmas in North Carolina, One Tree at a Time, After Hurricane Helene
description: The storm upended the Christmas tree industry in the state’s western region. Now, farmers and residents are eager for the comfort of the season’s rituals.
content: Curve around the mountain on a cool, wet morning, and you’ll see them rising through the fog: row after row of silver-green trees, their layers of soft needles and branches primed to hold a string of lights, a glittering bauble or a child’s handmade ornament.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives and Nazaneen Ghaffar
title: At Least 11 Dead as Cyclone Devastates Islands in Indian Ocean
description: The prefect of Mayotte said the death toll could climb. The storm, the equivalent of a Category 3, made landfall in Mozambique on Sunday.
content: Tropical Cyclone Chido made landfall in Mozambique on Sunday after causing destruction in Mayotte, a French archipelago of about 300,000 people in the Indian Ocean, where at least 11 people died, France’s interior ministry said on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin and Sarah Kessler
title: Google’s Sundar Pichai on Antitrust, Trump and A.I.
description: Google’s chief executive spoke with Andrew Ross Sorkin at the DealBook Summit
content: Google got a head start in the artificial intelligence race, and at the DealBook Summit on Dec. 4, its chief executive, Sundar Pichai, snapped back at suggestions that it should be more competitive considering its vast resources.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘At the End of the Bench, a Man Was Leaning Against the Railing’
description: Curiosity rewarded on the C train, a Christmas gift and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Genevieve Glatsky and María Silvia Trigo
title: Weeks of Upheaval Have Paralyzed This South American Nation. Here’s Why.
description: Protests in Bolivia triggered by a feud between the president and a political rival have caused turmoil. One fallout: fuel shortages that have left drivers lining up for gas for days.
content: Demonstrations have rocked Bolivia for more than two months. A longstanding political rivalry has boiled over, with supporters of the president and his chief opponent clashing in the streets. Protests have blocked the movement of goods, exacerbating fuel shortages. Some Bolivians lined up for days to buy gas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Calum Marsh
title: Four Years Later, CrossFit’s Disgraced Guru Attempts a Comeback
description: Greg Glassman, who sold the company amid sexual harassment complaints, has a new health and fitness venture. It sounds a lot like his old one.
content: In the summer of 2021, Josh Hunnicutt, a longtime personal trainer and the owner of the New Species CrossFit gym in Royal Oak, Mich., had a surprising opportunity: Greg Glassman, CrossFit’s contentious but charismatic co-founder, offered — more or less out of the blue — to pick him up in his private jet and fly him to a party in Ohio. The pitch was for the two of them to drink vodka sodas and rub elbows with other luminaries of the health and fitness industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyce McFadden and Nate Schweber
title: Weeks of Drone Sightings Leave New Jersey on Edge
description: In the Garden State, where the rash of sightings started a month ago, residents are looking to the skies, wondering why they still don’t have definitive answers from officials.
content: The day after Thanksgiving, Susan and Lorelai Woodruff saw approximately 10 brightly lit objects banking and turning quickly in the night sky above their home in Elsinboro, in southern New Jersey.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quote of the Day: In the Land of Christmas Trees, Hope After Helene
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, December 15, 2024
content: “There’s such a difference between hurting without hope and hurting with hope.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra E. Petri
title: ‘Malcolm in the Middle’ Is Getting a Four-Episode Revival on Disney+
description: The return of “Malcolm in the Middle,” which aired from 2000 to 2006, will follow Malcolm as he helps his parents celebrate their 40th wedding anniversary, Disney+ announced.
content: One of America’s wackiest families is making a comeback.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: Perfect Broiled Salmon, Beef Chow Fun and Mushroom Smash Burgers
description: A list of excellent recipes to cook this week (no need to check it twice).
content: Good morning. It’s list-making season. I’m cataloging gifts I want to give family and friends, tabulating all the work that needs to be done on the skiff before the fish return in the spring, putting basement chores on the docket, indexing every book I’ve read this year. I’m looking forward, looking back, taking stock and making plans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Jury Awards Woman $34 Million for Wrongful Conviction
description: Kirstin Blaise Lobato sued the Las Vegas Metropolitan Police Department and two detectives after she spent nearly 16 years in prison for a murder she did not commit.
content: Kirstin Blaise Lobato, who spent nearly 16 years in prison for a murder she did not commit, was awarded more than $34 million by a federal jury in Nevada on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles Lister
title: With al-Assad Gone, the Risk of an ISIS Resurgence Grows
description: With the fall of al-Assad’s regime, the risk of an ISIS resurgence increases.
content: After more than 53 years of a brutal dictatorship and nearly 14 years of debilitating conflict, the Assad government fell in just under two weeks. The sudden collapse of the regime — which killed, tortured and repressed countless Syrians — has brought a remarkable sense of unity and euphoria across longstanding divides in the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Jamie Foxx Recovering After Being Hit With a Glass in the Mouth
description: Foxx was celebrating his birthday at a restaurant on Friday when someone from another table threw a glass, a representative for the entertainer said.
content: The Oscar-winning actor, singer and comedian Jamie Foxx was recovering after a physical altercation at a restaurant on Friday night in which someone from another table threw a glass that hit him in the mouth, a representative for the entertainer and the police said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Ruberg and Nazaneen Ghaffar
title: Expect Icy Roads in Parts of the Northeast on Monday Morning
description: Light snow and freezing rain in parts of Connecticut, New Jersey and New York could make the commute hazardous, forecasters said.
content: Light snowfall and sleet overnight in parts of Connecticut, New Jersey, New York was expected to make roads icy for Monday morning commuters, forecasters said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil MacFarquhar and Justin Scheck
title: How Will the Rebels Rule Syria? Their Past Offers Clues.
description: The Islamist rebels who ousted Syria’s dictator ran a pragmatic and disciplined administration in the territory they controlled. They also jailed their critics.
content: Every fall, when farmers across the rolling, red dirt hills of Idlib Province in northern Syria harvest their olive crops, they routinely find at least one representative of the local tax authority stationed at any oil press.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Dec. 15, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Dec. 15, 2024.
content: A picture caption in the table of contents for an article on Dec. 1 about war and superbugs misidentified the type of testing being performed. Test strips were used to identify bacteria, not to test for antibiotic resistance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Williamson
title: Trump Names Richard Grenell for ‘Special Missions’ Role
description: A combative loyalist and the president-elect’s former ambassador to Germany, Mr. Grenell had hoped to be secretary of state.
content: President-elect Donald J. Trump named Richard Grenell, his former ambassador to Germany and former acting director of national intelligence, as his “envoy for special missions,” Mr. Trump wrote on his Truth Social platform on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gaya Gupta
title: Monday Briefing: South Korea’s Power Vacuum
description: Plus, how travel benefits us.
content: After South Korea’s National Assembly voted to impeach President Yoon Suk Yeol on Saturday, people celebrated his removal from office, even as the country was left with a political vacuum at the top that could last for months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: Devin Nunes, Pugnacious Trump Loyalist, to Lead Espionage Advisory Board
description: As chair of the House Intelligence Committee, he attacked the Russia inquiry and Donald J. Trump’s first impeachment. Now, Mr. Nunes runs Mr. Trump’s social media company.
content: President-elect Donald J. Trump announced on Saturday that he would appoint Devin Nunes, a former member of Congress who had used his role as chairman of the House Intelligence Committee to try to delegitimize the Trump-Russia investigation, to head an independent advisory board on espionage policy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Motoko Rich
title: As Ambassador, Rahm Emanuel Says His Impatience Nudged Japan Forward
description: In a society used to quiet consensus-building, Tokyo has made bold changes to its defense policy. “Did I contribute to that?” Mr. Emanuel asked. “Uh, yeah.”
content: Patience, Rahm Emanuel likes to say, is a waste of time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier and Arlette Bashizi
title: Security Strategy of Recruiting Cheap Militiamen Backfires in Africa
description: By arming civilians who are poorly trained and have little to no respect for human rights, the military in Burkina Faso has brought the West African nation to the brink of civil war.
content: They were falling asleep on a thin mat that they had been sharing since they were married five years ago. Suddenly, the roar of motorcycles woke them up. Armed men then dragged Rainatou Diallo and her husband, Adama Diallo, out of bed and into their courtyard.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Read the email from Revere’s principal
description: The email the principal of Revere High School sent to parents about the June 2023 cafeteria fight.
content: The email the principal of Revere High School sent to parents about the June 2023 cafeteria fight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Ley, Rebecca Lieberman and Eden Weingart
title: See How Much NYC's Congestion Pricing Plan Would Cost You
description: A new toll on drivers hopes to reduce traffic in one of the world’s most congested cities. How would it work?
content: A new toll on drivers hopes to reduce traffic in one of the world’s most congested cities. How would it work?
source.name: The New York Times
